<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 259]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 605]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 213, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 732, 905, 860]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2
Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 868, 611, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 71, 740, 88]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 94, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 594, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 490, 152]]<|/det|>
Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 160, 626, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 275, 528, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 180, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 305, 460, 324]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter reading \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 336, 923, 355]]<|/det|>
<form>E = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a metre rule with a wire attached. You have also been provided with two identical resistors placed in component holders, each labelled R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 485, 137]]<|/det|>
• Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 144, 834, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 380, 175, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>F</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 380, 423, 399]]<|/det|>
and G are crocodile clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 412, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
The distance between F and G is \(L\). Attach F and G to the wire so that \(L\) is approximately \(30 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 459, 171, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>Close</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 459, 339, 477]]<|/det|>
the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 489, 175, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>Record</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 489, 613, 508]]<|/det|>
the value of \(L\) and the voltmeter reading \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 520, 917, 537]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 549, 917, 567]]<|/det|>
<form>V = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 583, 171, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>Open</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 583, 336, 600]]<|/det|>
the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 598, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 72, 484, 91]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(E\) from (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 102, 922, 122]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 173, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Increase \(L\) by changing the position of F on the wire. Record \(L\) and \(V\) and repeat until you have six sets of values of \(L\) and \(V\). Include your values from (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 173, 764, 201]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{E - V}{L}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 144, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 533, 173, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 529, 690, 559]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{E - V}{L}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(V\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 567, 180, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 566, 457, 585]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 598, 180, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 597, 608, 617]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 782, 920, 801]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 814, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 831, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 725, 90]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(V\) and \(L\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 94, 567, 125]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{E - V}{L} = PV - Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 403, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 680, 183]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(d)**(iii), determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 346, 198]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 271, 917, 289]]<|/det|>
<form>P = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 303, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<form>Q = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 141, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 363, 369]]<|/det|>
The resistance of R is \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 339, 400]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 561, 431]]<|/det|>
· \(P\) and \(Q\) are both inversely proportional to \(R\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 717, 465]]<|/det|>
· the graph cuts the \(x\)-axis at a value of \(V = \frac{E}{2}\) for all values of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
A student repeats the experiment using two identical resistors, each with a lower value of \(R\) than in the original experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
For the student's experiment, draw a second line on the graph to show the expected results. Label this line W.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 551, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 568, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[55, 104, 76, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 764, 123]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the oscillations of a chain of paper clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 611, 152]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two spheres of modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 141, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 180, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 705, 184]]<|/det|>
The diameter of the **smaller** sphere is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 191, 549, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 300, 532, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 331, 384, 349]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 375, 925, 395]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 408, 181, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 408, 819, 427]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(d\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 564, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 72, 583, 90]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 100, 860, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 371, 534, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 403, 720, 421]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the rods are the same height above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 434, 720, 453]]<|/det|>
Slide the paper clips at the ends of the chain onto the rods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 466, 645, 484]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centres of the rods is \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 496, 665, 515]]<|/det|>
Position the stands so that \(x\) is approximately \(70 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 527, 420, 545]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 556, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
<form>x = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 556, 923, 575]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Use the hook to attach the **smaller** sphere of modelling clay to the chain of paper clips as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 114, 668, 357]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 368, 534, 387]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2.3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 400, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
The number of paper clips between the hook and the end of the chain is \(n\), as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 446, 487, 465]]<|/det|>
Place the hook so that \(n\) is 11.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 477, 395, 495]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(N\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 502, 541, 526]]<|/det|>
\[N = \sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{n^2}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 537, 601, 557]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to three significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<form>N = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 663, 144, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 662, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
Pull the sphere towards you through a short distance. When the sphere is released, it will oscillate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 708, 180, 726]]<|/det|>
